task_summary: Perceive the T-shaped block, align the circular end-effector to a side face, push it toward the marked goal, then retreat.

task_long_description.overview: A UR-style arm with a circular tool must push a T-shaped block across a flat white surface to a fixed target mark. The behavior emphasizes reliable perception, safe approach without grasping, orientation alignment to the block’s side, and a controlled push along a single direction. The contact sheet shows initial perception, side alignment, sustained pushing, and final retreat. Observation and control run at 10 Hz; we select moderate timeouts and a precise alignment tolerance to keep the push stable without overconstraining execution.
preconditions: T-shaped block is on the table
Target mark exists on the surface
Arm is homed and tool is free (no grasp)
stepwise_plan: If the block is not immediately visible, scan the workspace
Move above the block at safe height
Set tool yaw for lateral pushing
Approach and align to the side of the T with tight tolerance
Push the block toward the target direction
Retreat to a safe pose and pause briefly
success_criteria: Block center reaches the goal region
Continuous contact during the push without slipping
failure_and_recovery: Block not visible → raster scan and retry detection
Insufficient displacement → repeat Push with same direction
task_long_description.termination: End after retreat once the push action completes and the robot is idle.

frame_3.now_evidence: first stable contact and alignment cue visible
frame_3.predicts_next: push actuation expected; confirms goal direction

task_instruction: The task requires pushing a T-shaped block (gray) to a fixed target (green) with a circular end-effector (blue). Both observation and control frequencies are 10Hz.

node_specs.description: Checks visibility of the T block.
Raster scan to find the block if not visible.
Run detection to localize the block.
Move above the block to a safe height.
Approach the side and align before pushing.
Execute the push toward the goal direction.
Back off to a safe distance.

failure_modes: Tool yaw incorrect for contact face
assumptions: Frames show a red T block and a faint blue circle as target; instruction mentions gray block and green target—treated as the same objects.
Push direction chosen as 90° (camera-right) based on displacement cues.
No grasping required; pure pushing contact.

expected_success_criteria: Block reaches target region and remains there
